title: The thug who hit a man on the head with a hammer five times - and his wife who cleaned up after him
text:

A man was left left for dead after being hit on the head with a hammer five times in a ‘sadistic’ attack in broad daylight. 
Thomas Ward was repeatedly struck outside a shop in Gorton at about 8.30am on June 12 by Keith O’Shea. 
O’Shea has now been jailed for eight years, and was given an extended sentence of four years after a judge ruled he posed a significant risk of serious harm to the public. 
His wife Rachel O’Shea was spared jail, after being convicted on joint enterprise despite not having attacked Mr Ward. 
Shocking CCTV footage played in court showed Mr Ward lifeless on the floor following the incident, until he gets up and is helped by a passerby. Read More Coroner orders 'the other Aki' to come to Stephen Akinyemi inquest 
The court heard that Rachel O’Shea and Mr Ward had been involved in a verbal spat shortly before the incident. 
Prosecuting, Simon Barrett said police were initially called to Constable Street in Abbey Hey after receiving a tip off that a man had been assaulted. Keith O'Shea 
They were then directed to a home nearby where they found Mr Ward, who had suffered serious injuries. 
There was blood on the door frame, and Mr Ward had suffered deep cuts to his head. 
But he refused to co-operate with the police and discharged himself from hospital on his first visit, returning the next day to get his cuts treated. Read More 
Police made further enquiries and tracked down CCTV footage from the street which showed Keith O’Shea chasing Mr Ward before catching up with him, pinning him to the ground and hitting him with a claw hammer five times. 
Mr Ward lays lifeless for several minutes before he gets up. 
The footage then shows Rachel O’Shea re-emerge, pouring water on Mr Ward’s head, in what Judge Martin Steiger described as a ‘contemptuous attempt to revive him into consciousness’. Read More McDonald's has switched off free wi-fi to stop troublemakers using the restaurant 'as a youth club' 
She later poured detergent on the floor in a bid to clear up the pool of blood left behind following the attack. 
Police identified Keith and Rachel O’Shea from the footage and arrested them in separate locations on July 9. 
In a basis of plea document submitted to the court, Keith O’Shea claimed that he was ‘terrified’ of Mr Ward, saying that he threatened him with a knife shortly before the CCTV footage started. Manchester Crown Court 
The court was told that Mr Ward, aged in his 40s, has a ‘significant’ criminal record. 
But Keith O’Shea admitted he had gone too far. 
Defending him, Gwen Henshaw said the incident was ‘impulsive’ and ‘reactionary’ and that he is now remorseful. 
The court was told Keith O’Shea was previously sentenced to 10 years in prison in 1995 for kidnap and rape. 
He was jailed for 10 years again in 2003, for possessing a firearm with intent to cause fear of violence. 
Rachel O’Shea’s defence lawyer, Max Saffman, said she has no previous violent convictions. 
Judge Steiger said: “Some form of altercation had taken place between Rachel O’Shea and Mr Ward, a man in his 40s with a significant criminal record. 
“For reasons unexplained the male defendant went to his address, took a hammer and repeatedly struck him at a time when Ward was on the ground. 
“This was an extended attack with no fewer than five blows with a hammer. 
“Her [Rachel O’Shea’s] offending is much less serious even though she encouraged her partner to continue this disgraceful and shocking act.” 
Keith O’Shea, 43, of Constable Street, Gorton, pleaded guilty to wounding with intent, possession of an offensive weapon, and possession of heroin. 
Rachel O’Shea, 42, also of Constable Street, pleaded guilty to unlawful wounding, and theft related to a separate incident. 
She was sentenced to 18 months in prison suspended for two years and must undertaken a six month drug rehabilitation scheme. Like us on Facebook
